Mr. Jones said he should be glad to see Mrs. Day, then I went with the prisoner to Mrs. Day, at the hoop and petticoat warehouse; I went in and asked if that was Mrs. Day's, she was not at home, the prisoner asked young Mr. and Mrs. Lightowler, whether they had not a brother cast away in the Ville de Paris; they said they had; I said, Mr. Jones, the proctor would be glad if Mrs. Day could come to him; they both of them looked at the will, and they said they believed that must be a forged will; young Mrs. Lightowler says to her brother, go next door and fetch Mr. Carpmeal, the officer; the man said they might fetch whom they would: no officer came, and we were at full liberty; Mrs. Day said, at the examination, she looked upon some part of the will to be her son's hand writing: we went into the
Brown Bear
.
What ship did Wagg belong to? - I do not know.
Court. Look when the deceased was turned over from the Triumph to the Prince William? - The 21st of June, 1781.
Lightowler. I saw my brother the 5th of November, and twenty-four days before this was executed, my brother came on board the Barsleur to see me, he was then upon very good terms with all the family.
Prisoner. Ask him, whether he did not acknowledge the hand writing to be his brother's hand writing?
PRISONER's DEFENCE.

In the first place, when I saw Mr. Lightowler, he was very genteelly dressed; he was going to sell a white shirt that very day, when I first became acquainted with him, I did not belong to a King's ship, he had a blue coat on, he used to use a house that I did, seeing he was a man of war's officer, I lent him money many different times; when I was going away from New York to
Charles Town
, he said to me, I will make you a will to take to England.

Who was
James Murray
? - He was a man that lived on me, and Williams kept the Plate of Oysters, in the Fly Market at New York; I told Mr. Lightowler my witnesses were at New York.

GEORGE COMFORD
sworn.
I have known the prisoner a great many years, I never saw any thing of him but a very honest man, as far as ever I knew.
What are you? - I keep a clothes-shop in Rosemary-lane.
What is the prisoner? - A seaman.
Can he read and write? - Not that I know of, I never saw him write.

JANE WRIGHT
sworn.
I have known the prisoner, he has lived with me two years.
What character does he bear? - A very good one, he was a very sober, honest man.
Where do you live? - In Virginia-street.

Court to M'Lane. I think you say you succeeded Lightowler as Captain's clerk? - Not immediately, there was one intervened, I was on board when Lightowler was turned off as Captain's clerk, the 15th of April 1782, he continued Captain's clerk till he left the ship.
In what situation did he go on board the Formidable? - In the same situation.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the second London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

200.
LAWRENCE CARTER
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Howarth
, Esquire , on the 14th of November , on the King's highway, putting him in fear and danger of his life, and feloniously taking from his person and against his will, one steal watch chain, value 12 d. one white cornelian seal, set in gold, value 20 s. one red cornelian seal, set in gold, value 20 s. and one crystal seal, set in gold, value 20 s. his property .

JOHN HOWARTH
, Esq; sworn.

On Sunday evening, the 14th of November last, between ten and eleven, I was going home down by Charing-cross
, on the side next Whitehall, I had a gentleman with me in company, my chain hung out of my pocket, a man snatched at my watch, I had then no great coat on, and my watch chain was very visible; I put my hand, and found the seals were gone, but my watch was left; I cannot describe who took them.

John Cooper
, a pawnbroker, produced one of the seals, which had been pawned by
Anna Maria Bousted
, who said she had them of the prisoner, and the prisoner said he picked them up under some hay, near Johnson's-court, Charing-cross.
Bousted deposed to the same effect.
Prisoner. I found the things.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. ROSE.

201.
JOHN CHAMBERS
was indicted, for
that he, well knowing that one
James Witty
, deceased, had lately served our Lord the King on board the Exeter, and that certain wages and pay were due to him, on the 23d of October last, feloniously did utter and publish as true, a certain false, forged, and counterfeited paper, purporting to be a last will, dated the 4th of December, devising the same to the said
Thomas Chambers
, and appointing him executor thereof, in order to receive the said wages and pay, due to the said
James Witty
.
Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Council. The will purports to be a last will.
Mr. Silvester, Council for the Prosecution. The act says,
"if any person shall forge a will."
Court. But it must be the will of somebody.
Court to Jury. Gentlemen, as we are of opinion, in this case, the indictment is defective, it is unnecessary to trouble you with evidence.
NOT GUILTY .
Tried by the second London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

202.
JOHN MILES
was indicted for
that he, on the 5th day of October , feloniously and falsely did make, forge, and counterfeit, a certain deed, purporting to be a bill of sale, of
Robert
M'Cormick, seaman, lately belonging to the East India ship, called the Earl of Talbot, in consideration of ten pounds eighteen shillings, paid by
Daniel
M'Cartey, purporting to be a bill of sale to the said
Daniel
M'Cartey, of all his wages and pay due to him, as his, and their own proper goods and chattles, and to his and their own proper use and uses for ever; which said bill of sale was dated the 5th of October, 1784, and sealed and delivered in the presence of
Nathaniel Darby
, and
Keefe O Keefe
, with intent to defraud the said
Daniel M'Cartey
.
A second count for uttering the same, with a like intention.

The prosecutor and one of the subscribing witnesses could not identify the prisoner, but the other subscribing witness swore positively to him, the prisoner in his defence said M'Cormick owed him five guineas, and gave him a note for that ship, which he sold to the prosecutor, as other young fellows had done, he went on board the next day to M'Cormick, who paid him what he owed him, and gave him half a guinea for his trouble.
The Prisoner called one witness who gave him a good character.
The Jury retired for a short time, and returned with a verdict
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the first Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

203.
LEWIS HENRY SCIPIO DUROURE
, late of St. Paul's, Covent Garden
, in the County of Middlesex, Esq ; was indicted for
that he, being an evil disposed person, and of a wicked disposition, after the 1st of June, 1723, to wit on the 21st of November last, with force and arms, in the Parish aforesaid, with a certain pistol, loaded with gunpowder, and a leaden bullet, which pistol he then and there had and held in his right hand, unlawfully, wilfully, maliciously and feloniously, did shoot at one
Huxley Sandon
, Esq ; the said Huxley Sandon, then and there being in the peace of God and our Lord the King, in the dwelling house of
James Brewer
and
John Sandy
, against the form of the statute, and against the King's peace .
The indictment was opened by Mr. Chetwood as follows.

My Lord and Gentlemen of the Jury, This is an indictment as you have heard against the gentleman at the bar, for wilfully and maliciously firing at Huxley Sandon, Esq; a loaded pistol: Gentlemen there is no attempt on the part of the prosecutor, to carry this further than the facts will go, therefore I shall only say in opening this case to you, that the prosecutor and the prisoner, had been for a long time in habits of friendship, the prisoner always had access to the house of the prosecutor, and they were in great friendship and intimacy; sometime since it was supposed the prisoner was going to France, or Italy, and he went to the house of the prosecutor, and prevailed on the wife of the prosecutor to accompany him to Dover, and accordingly she did accompany him to Dover; the prosecutor enraged and angry at that time, no doubt of it, pursued his wife and his friend to Dover, however they cluded the search, and came back to town: Information was given after several endeavours to find them, that they were at a Bagnio, in Long Acre, the prosecutor and his friends went to search there, they were denied, but the prosecutor and his friends had reason to think that they either were in the house, or coming to the house, as they had been in the house, and were very well known there, the man said at first they were not there, and he did not know them. However from several expressions, the prosecutor and his friends were convinced that they did know the prisoner, and in a little while after they heard the feet of two people walking, as if in great confusion over their heads, and they were then pretty well satisfied, that the prisoner at the bar was in the house, and was in company with Mrs. Sandon, who has been the unfortunate cause of this prosecution; Gentlemen, the prosecutor and his friends went up stairs, there they met a servant, coming out of a room with a candle in her hand, and one of the friends of the prosecutor took a candle from her, and they were going to enter the room, Mr.
Sandon
the husband, was going in first, he was willing and desirous to be thoroughly satisfied, whether the prisoner and his wife were there or not, and immediately a pistol was fired by somebody; that it was loaded, was most certain, because the ball passed through a part of his hat, there was no light in the room at the time, but however, he saw by the firing of the pistol, that it was perhaps the prisoner at the bar, he was pretty positive at that time, however, they called fresh assistance and took the prisoner and Mrs. Sandon; the witnesses will inform you, in what situation they found the prisoner at the bar, and how they found Mrs. Sandon, I believe they were both armed at that time, Mrs. Sandon had pistols loaded in her hand, as well as the prisoner; whether or no, the prisoner was the person that fired the pistol at Mr. Sandon, it will be for you to enquire; there is little doubt, I should apprehend, that it will be proved to be him; if you find that he fired the pistol, you will have no difficulty in pronouncing him guilty of shooting, maliciously and feloniously, against Mr. Sandon: Gentlemen, we shall call our witnesses and prove the facts; and if you believe he was the person that fired the pistol at the prosecutor, you will find him guilty.

MARY JONES
sworn.
Examined by Mr. Chetwood. Where do you live? - At the Royal Hotel, in Long Acre.
Did you live there in October last? - Yes?
Did you ever see the prisoner at the bar? - Yes.
Did you ever see him at that house? - Yes.
Do you remember him there on the 24th of October, and do you remember Mr. Sandon, the prosecutor, coming to that house? - Yes.
Was the prisoner in the house at that time? - No Sir, not when they came in first, he was out.
Did he come in during the time Mr. Sandon was there? - Yes, and he went up stairs into the room.
Who was with him? - A lady.
Did you see Mr. Sandon go up stairs afterwards? - No, I was in the room with the Count, at the time they came up stairs.

Did you come out of the room and see Mr. Sandon? - I came out of the room, but I do not recollect seeing Mr. Sandon; I was in the room, and the Lady said she would fire at the first person that came into the room, the bell rang in the room where the Count and the lady were, and I answered the bell.

Were they armed? - The lady was, but I do not recollect seeing pistols in the Count's hands, I saw pistols in the lady's hands, the lady said she would fire at the first that came in, for she would sooner die than go with them.

Did the lady mention any names, or had any been mentioned to her? - No Sir, she said she would kill the first that came in, she would fire at the first that came in, for she would sooner die, than go with them.
(The Count desired a chair that he might sit down to take notes. A chair ordered.)

When you came out of the room, did you leave any candle in the room? - I brought out the candle, and somebody took the candle, but who it was I cannot say, I did not stop a moment, I was frightened and came down stairs.
Mr. Erskine, and Mr. Garrow, Prisoner's Council.

Mr. Erskine. Pray my girl, had Mrs.
Sandon
any more pistols than one? - She had two, I do not recollect the count had any, she was dressed in mens cloaths, and had a pistol in each hand.
You are sure it was her, that said she would fire at the first man that came in? - Yes.
What house is this? - The Royal Hotel, in Long Acre, I live there as a servant.

Who is this house kept by? - By Mr.
James Soundy
, and
John Brewer
, they are partners.
You are the servant? - Yes.

What is Mr. Brewer's
Christian Name
? - John.

What is Mr. Sandy's Name? -
James Soundy
.
Mr. Erskine. Then there is an end of it; my Lord, I submit here is a fatal variance on the indictment.
Court to Mr. Chetwood. What do you say to this? - Mr. Chetwood, I submit it may be considered as surplusage.
Mr. Erskine. It is too plain, it is A. B. C.

Court. Gentlemen of the Jury, there can be no doubt at all in this case, they have taken upon themselves to state in the indictment, whose house it is; I do not know that it was necessary for them to have so done, but having done it, they are bound in point of law to prove it, and the evidence turns out that it is not the dwelling house of
James Brewer
and
John Sandy
, but of
James Soundy
and
John Brewer
, that is a fatal variance in the indictment, and where a man is charged on a capital offence, strict law is adhered to, so that you cannot do any thing but acquit him.
NOT GUILTY .

Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr.
Baron HOTHAM
.

204.
MARGARET SMALL
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 15th day of October , one feather bed, value 5 l. three blankets, value 20 s. and a counterpane, value 20 s. the property of
Rice Jones
, stolen by a certain ill disposed person, well knowing the same to have been feloniously stolen .
GUILTY .

To be
fined 1 s. and
imprisoned two years in Newgate .
Tried by the third London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.
OPINION of the JUDGES,
On the Case of Humphy Moore, who was tried in April Sessions last, delivered by Mr. Justice WILLES.

88.
HUMPHRY MOORE
, you was indicted last April sessions, for feloniously stealing twenty guineas and four doubloons, value 14 l. 8 s. the property of
John Field
, in the dwelling house of John Brown, it appeared in evidence, that a person unknown joined company with the prosecutor
John Field
, in the street, and soon after picked up a purse, and persuaded the prosecutor to go to a publick house with him, telling him he was intitled to half; the person took out a receipt, and whilst they were looking at it, you came into the room, and asked if there was any thing extraordinary, and being told by the unknown person, you said, which of you picked it up? and the prosecutor said he had forty or fifty pounds, at his lodgings at Chelsea; upon which you said we will call a coach and go there, and you all three went to Chelsea, and drank a shilling's worth of punch, that they found you afterwards at the Cheshire-cheese, and in your presence, the prosecutor put down the money twenty guineas, and four doubloons, which the person unknown took up and carried away, leaving the ring with the prosecutor; and appointed to meet him the next day, to have the money returned, and one hundred pounds for his share of the ring; that the person unknown, and you went away together, and the prosecutor went to the place of appointment, but neither you nor the person unknown came; the ring was proved to be of very small value, and the jury were of opinion you was confederating with the person unknown, for the purpose of obtaining money, and sharing the value of the ring, and therefore, that you did aid and assist the person unknown, to obtain the money of the prosecutor
John Field
; and the jury found you guilty - Subject to the opinion of the Court.

This matter was submitted to the opinion of all the Judges the first day of last Michaelmas term, except Lord Mansfield, who was absent, and they all agreed in the distinction between the parting with the possession, and the parting with the property; that in the first case it was felony, and in the last case it was not; nine of the Judges were of opinion, that in this case possession only was parted with, it being only a pledge, till the supposed value of the ring was delivered; two of the Judges thought that the doubloons were the same as money, and were of opinion it was a loan, and was a parting with the property, but nine of the Judges were of opinion it was felony; and the Judges could not distinguish this from the case of the King and Patch, that case was this; the prisoner was indicted for stealing a watch, and some money, the prisoner picked up a ring and purse in the street, the prisoner pretending he found it, offered to divide the money with the prosecutor, and opening the purse, there was a ring, and bill of parcels, stating the ring to be a diamond one, of one hundred and forty seven pounds value, and a receipt for that sum different modes were proposed for the distribution, at last the prisoner asked the prosecutor if he would give him his money and watch, and take the ring; two other men that were in company took up the watch and money, and the prisoner got the prosecutor out of the room under pretence he had something particular to say to him, and the two men ran away with the watch and money; the person was uneasy, and the prisoner said he knew the two men: The prisoner was apprehended, and the ring was found to be of the value of ten shillings only: It was objected by the councel, for the prisoner that was not a felony, but Mr. Justice Gould, Mr.
Baron Perryn
, and Mr. Justice Buller, held it should be left to the Jury to say, what was the intention of the prisoner, to get the money and watch, for if the whole was a scheme of the three men, it was felony, according to the case of the King and Peers, where a horse was hired for the day, by two men, who went directly and sold him: and Mr. Justice Gould left it to the Jury, whether the prisoner, and the other two men were not all in concert together; upon the whole therefore, of your case the majority of the Judges are of opinion that you are guilty of the felony, and not merely of a fraud, and that judgment must be passed upon you accordingly.

Mr. Recorder. Humphry Moore, when upon your trial I reserved this case, it was not from any doubt of your guilt, but doubting whether your guilt was of that kind to support the indictment, that doubt has been submitted to the opinion of all the Judges, and a great majority of them have concurred in opinion, that the indictment was sufficiently supported, by the circumstances given in evidence against you; I never entertained any doubt, that the offence of which you was clearly proved to be guilty, was deserving of as high a punishment, as any felony committed under similar circumstances, if therefore no doubt in point of law had occured, I should have passed sentence upon you, to be transported for seven years; no reason occurs now, for changing that opinion of your offence, but as the necessity of laying your case before the Judges, has occasioned some delay, and a considerable time has elapsed since your conviction, I shall take care the term of your transportation shall be computed from the time of your conviction, therefore the sentence of the court is, that you Humphry Moore,
be transported beyond the seas, for the term of seven years, from the time of your conviction, to such place or places, as his Majesty by the advice of his privy council shall thing fit to direct or appoint .

Richard Marsh
was called to the bar, and informed by the Court, that his case was reserved till the opinion of the twelve Judges on the case of Humphry Moore was declared, as it was governed by that, being exactly similar, and there was no ground, either in fact or law, for drawing any distinction between them; and the Judges having declared their opinion, that the case of Moore amounted to a felonious stealing, the sentence of the Court upon him the said
Richard Marsh
was, to be
transported for seven years .

rs.p:
Robert Abel
, capitally convicted at a former Sessions, received his Majesty's pardon, upon condition of being transported for seven years.

div1.p: ERRATA.

In the first Trial of
Richard Smith
, for Guilty, read, Not Guilty.
In the second Trial of ditto, for Guilty, read, Guilty, Death.

In the Trial of
Edward Garth
, for Guilty, read, Guilty, Death.

In the Trial of
Richard Hobson
, for Guilty, read, Guilty, Death.
The Sessions being ended, the Court proceeded to give Judgment as follows:
Received sentence of death, 31.

James Dunn
,
John Evans
,
George Robinson
,
James Hamilton
,
William Stewart
,
William Astell
,
William Giles
,
Philip Patch
,
Henry Rutter
,
Allen Williams
,
Thomas Tabbs
,
George Harris
,
John Shaw
,
Thomas Buttledoze
,
John Moody
,
Richard Smith
,
Thomas Cale
,
George Goldsmith
, Laurence Hall,
John Jones
,
Richard Hobson
,
William Finder
,
William Abbott
,
John Kelsey
,
William Benton
,
Melvin Simmons
,
Edward Garth
,
James Smith
,
Ferdinand Dowland
,
Samuel Warner
, and
Edward Johnson
.
To be transported for fourteen years, 1.

Elizabeth Colley
.
To be transported for seven years, 39.

Charles Stone
,
Andrew Simms
,
John Jeff
,
William Smart
,
Joseph Davis
,
John
M'Gowan,
William Cox
,
Alexander
M'Donald,
Thomas Watson
,
James Davis
,
James Thomas
,
Isaac Warren
,
John Cashon
, William Hall,
Benjamin Ingram
,
Thomas Wale
,
Luke Rogers
,
William Gilbert
,
Edward Humphreys
,
Michael Sullivan
,
George Francisco
,
Edward Brett
, Israel Silcock,
Mary Bramham
,
Robert Jones
,
Benjamin West
,
James Hobbs
,
Charles Medley
,
Catherine Hart
,
Nicholas Greenwell
,
Robert Freeman
,
Dennis Hayes
,
Jonathan Payne
,
William Bacot
,
Isaac Dukes
,
George Newton
,
William Thomas
,
Thomas Clar
ke, and
Nicholas English
.
To be imprisoned in Newgate two years, 1.

Margaret Small
.
To be confined to hard labour twelve months in the House of Correction, 3.

William Nobes
,
Mary Horton
, and
Margaret Murphy
.
To be confined to hard labour six months in the House of Correction, 8.

Thomas Bolton
,
Richard Brady
,
William Wills
,
William Smith

Robert Jones
.

Richard Marsh
was called to the bar, and informed by the Court, that his case was reserved till the opinion of the twelve Judges on the case of Humphry Moore was declared, as it was governed by that, being exactly similar, and there was no ground, either in fact or law, for drawing any distinction between them; and the Judges having declared their opinion, that the case of Moore amounted to a felonious stealing, the sentence of the Court upon him the said
Richard Marsh
was, to be
transported for seven years .

John Westwood
was ordered to remain till next Sessions.
Hickman and Dias to remain on their former order.

rs.p:
Robert Abel
, capitally convicted at a former Sessions, received his Majesty's pardon, upon condition of being transported for seven years.

div1.p:
John Ruglass
, a transport to the coast of Africa, who had been found at large, was set to the bar, and confessed he was the man that had received his Majesty's pardon, on condition of being so transported; but alledged, that Governor Lacey, the Governor of the island, sent them off, and would not give them any victuals: he was ordered to remain under under his former sentence, and told he must represent his case to the King, and apply to him for mercy.
HODGSON, PROFESSOR of SHORT-HAND, and SHORT-HAND WRITER to the OLD-BAILEY, At No. 35, CHANCERY-LANE,

Respectfully thanks the Gentlemen of the learned Professions, and others, for their flattering Partiality to his Compendious SYSTEM of SHORT-HAND, which is Taught, as usual, in FOUR LESSONS ONLY, at 10 s. 6 d. each.
Trials, Arguments, &c. taken with Precision and Care, and expeditiously transcribed, on reasonable Terms.
A new Impression of his Second Edition of Short-hand, Price 2 s. 6 d. to be had as above; also of BLADON, Paternoster-row, and CLARKE, Portugal-street.

In the Press, and speedily will be published, Price only 2 s. 6 d. A Collection of CHARACTERS, Arbitrary and Symbolical, for the Benefit of SHORT-HAND WRITERS, and adapted to every System; with a comparative Table of Short-hand Alphabets, by E. HODGSON.
N. B. The Table may then be had separate, Price 6 d.
